translated: Jātaka: Birth Stories
Book 7
The Fowl Chapter
The Birth Story of Sattubhasta
“Your mind is disturbed, your senses are agitated,
From your eyes streams of water flow.

original: Kiṁ te naṭṭhaṁ kiṁ pana patthayāno,
analyzed: kim te naṭṭham kim pana patthayāno
translated: What have you lost? What are you seeking,

analyzed: idha agama brahme tat iṅgha brūhi
translated: That you have come here, Brahmā? Tell me that.”
“My wife might have died while I was away,
Or a yakkha might have said I would die if I returned.
I am disturbed by this sorrow,
So tell me, Senaka, what this means.”
“Having considered many possibilities,

analyzed: yam ettha vakkhāmi tat eva sat ca
translated: I will tell you only what is true.
I think, brahmin, that you have a snake in your staff,
And that you do not know it.

original: Ādāya daṇḍaṁ parisumbha bhastaṁ,🔽Passeḷamūgaṁ uragaṁ dujivhaṁ;
analyzed: ādāya daṇḍam parisumbha bhasta  uragam dujivha
translated: Take your staff, shake it well,🔽And look at the dumb, blind, double-tongued snake.
Cut off your doubts and uncertainties,
And look at the snake! Let go of your staff!”
In the midst of the assembly, his body trembling,

original: So brāhmaṇo sattubhastaṁ pamuñci;🔽Atha nikkhami urago uggatejo,
analyzed: saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ sattubhaḥ tam pamuñci  atha nikkhami uragaḥ ugga tejaḥ
translated: The brahmin let go of his staff.🔽Then the snake emerged, with great splendor,
The poisonous snake, with its hood spread out.

analyzed: su laddha lābhā janakassa rañño  yaḥ passati senakam sādhu pañña
translated: “Happy is King Janaka,🔽Who sees the wise Senaka;
Open-mouthed he looks at him, all-seeing,
Is it knowledge, Brahman, that is so terrible?”
“These seven hundred are mine,
Take them all, I give them to you;

analyzed: tayā hi me jīvita majja laddha
translated: For I have now received my life back,
And I have made my wife safe.”
“The wise do not accept wages,
With various verses and good sayings;

analyzed: itas upi te brahme dadantu vitta
translated: Let them give you wealth, Brahman,
And you, having received it, go to your own home.”
The Sattubhastajātaka is the seventh.
